title: 108_hr5179
content: The "Social Security Solvency Act of 2004" may adjust the rate of increase in contribution and benefit base. Section 230(b)(2) of the Social Security Act is amended to adjust the contribution and benefit base for calendar years after 2005 and before 2037. The amendment to the Social Security Act introduces the use of the chained consumer price index for determining cost-of-living increases in benefits. This change applies to increases starting from December of calendar years after 2005. Additionally, the retention of the estate tax and transfers to the Social Security Trust Fund are addressed. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 makes the exclusion equivalent permanent at the 2009 amount of $3,500,000. Conforming amendments repeal certain sections of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude certain sections of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. This Act shall not apply to taxable years after December 31, 2010. Amounts equivalent to taxes received under specific chapters are appropriated to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude sections of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Taxes received under specific chapters are appropriated to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund. Amounts appropriated shall be transferred from the general fund of the Treasury based on estimates made by the Secretary of the Treasury. Quarterly payments will be made on the first day of each quarter, with adjustments made as needed. The Secretary of the Treasury will submit annual reports to Congress and the Commissioner of Social Security. The Secretary of the Treasury will submit annual reports to Congress and the Commissioner of Social Security regarding the transfers made under this subsection during the year, the methodology used in determining the amount of such transfers, and the anticipated operation of this subsection during the next 5 years. SEC. 5. FUTURE ADJUSTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT TAX RATES TO KEEP SOCIAL SECURITY TRUST FUNDS IN BALANCE. The amendment to Section 201(c) of the Social Security Act requires the Board of Trustees to provide their best estimate of the date when the Trust Funds will not have enough assets to pay full benefits on time. If this date is within 2 years of the report, a minimum tax increase is necessary to prevent this insufficiency. The amendment to Section 201(c) of the Social Security Act requires a tax increase to prevent insufficiency in Trust Funds when assets are insufficient to pay full benefits on time. The tax rate will be adjusted as necessary to address this issue. The tax rates for old-age, survivors, and disability insurance will be increased to prevent insufficiency in Trust Funds when assets are insufficient to pay full benefits on time. The Secretary will prescribe the necessary rate adjustments.
